name: Chimera
abilities: Petrifying Gaze: Anyone who looks directly at her face turns instantly to stone
Serpent Hair: Living, venomous snakes that writhe and strike independently
Flight: Golden wings enable swift aerial movement

weaknesses: Mirrors: Cannot see her own reflection without petrifying herself
Indirect Vision: Can be fought by reflecting her gaze or using periphery
Mortal Body: Despite her powers, her physical form can be wounded
Emotional Vulnerability: Attachment can cloud her judgment
habitat: Solitary caves and temples, places of desolation
behavior: Victim turned protector, vengeful yet sympathetic, isolation-driven

christian.overview: The Chimera's composite form (lion, goat, serpent) breathing fire prefigures Christian imagery of composite beasts representing sin and demonic powers.

biblicalParallels.description: The apocalyptic horses with lion heads and serpent tails echo the Chimera.
Daniel's composite beasts anticipate the Chimera tradition of unnatural combinations.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers saw the Chimera as representing disordered passions overcome by virtue.

sources.author: Fulgentius
sources.interpretation: The lion represents anger, the goat represents lust, the serpent represents consequences.

sources.author: Isidore of Seville
sources.interpretation: Represents life stages consumed by passion.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: An example of deception and impossibility - sin creates monsters within us.
medievalSymbolism.moralLesson: Only slain by the hero of virtue mounted on divine grace (Pegasus).

christian.typologicalReading: Bellerophon's aerial defeat of the Chimera prefigures Christ's victory from the Cross.
scholarlyReferences: Chance, Jane. Medieval Mythography. University Press of Florida, 1994.
